foods.name: Pepian
foods.special_fact: Pepián is one of Guatemala’s oldest dishes and is often considered the national dish. It blends Mayan and Spanish influences in a rich, thick stew.

foods.name: Kak'ik
foods.special_fact: Kak'ik is a traditional Mayan soup with a bright red color, symbolizing blood and life. It’s typically served with rice and tamales.

foods.name: Jocon
foods.special_fact: This bright green stew gets its color from tomatillos and cilantro. It is particularly popular in the western highlands of Guatemala.

foods.name: Fiambre
foods.special_fact: Fiambre is a unique cold salad traditionally eaten on November 1st (All Saints’ Day). Families prepare it together to honor deceased loved ones.

foods.name: Tamales Colorados
foods.special_fact: Guatemalan red tamales are wrapped in banana leaves instead of corn husks, giving them a distinct aroma and flavor.

foods.name: Rellenitos de Plátano
foods.special_fact: These sweet fried plantain balls are filled with refried black beans and sugar — a popular dessert or snack found across Guatemala.
